An element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ with respect to a ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ if it satisfies any of the equivalent conditions: (i) there exists an integral equation of $b$ over $A$, i.e., an equation of type $f(b)=0$ for a monic polynomial $f \in A[X]$, (ii) the subring $A[b] \subset B$, viewed as an $A$-module, is finitely generated, (iii) viewing $B$ as an $A$-module, there exists a finitely generated submodule $M=\sum_{i=1}^{n} A m_{i} \subset B$ such that $1 \in M$ and $b M \subset M$.
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: A \longrightarrow B$ is integral if every element $b \in B$ is integral over $A$ in the way described in the definition of an integral element over a ring.
Does the concept of a/an Integral Element over a Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Integral Ring Homomorphism to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of an Integral Ring Homomorphism explicitly relies on the concept of an element being integral over a ring. According to the provided definition, a ring homomorphism \(\varphi: A \longrightarrow B\) is integral if every element \(b \in B\) is integral over \(A\) as defined by the concept of an Integral Element over a Ring. This means that for the definition of an Integral Ring Homomorphism to be meaningful and applicable, the concept of an Integral Element over a Ring must first be established and understood. Without this foundational concept, the definition of an Integral Ring Homomorphism would lack the necessary criteria to determine whether a given homomorphism is integral or not, as it directly depends on whether elements of \(B\) satisfy the conditions of being integral over \(A\).
